text: caramel, chocolate, roasty, resin, dough, earthy, alcohol, woody, red, copper,clear, tan foam, light sweetness, light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, average carbonation,

Coming home from a kids swim birthday party with a bunch of small kids and fortunately I had a growler of this in the fridge. Dark with a small head. Poured quickly and that was a big plus.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Sampled at GABF 2015. In the glass was red . White head. Nose of nuts and fruit. Medium body. Flavor is earth and nutty. Bitter finish. Nice/.

Bottle. This beer pours a fairly dark brown color that turns a rich shade of ruby when put to the light. A tall head of light tan forms atop the beer as well. Very pretty.

The aroma on this was a little weak. Grainy and dusty smelling with perhaps a latent sweetness.

The flavor however is much better than the aroma. Lots of lovely sweet notes and caramel malts come through. It is a smooth and slick sweetness that blends well with the surrounding grains and malts. Light bitterness on the finish with just the slightest amount of tingle over the palate.

While I’ll admit I wasn’t much into the aroma, the flavor really came through in a big way. Very tasty.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Ive been looking for a good Scottish Ale for years it seems. This one very drinkable. Color right to style, very low carbonation, good. Flavor is nicely balanced malt-hops-peaty-smoke... they got that right. Only negative may be the water... hence the dissappearing act of any lacing. Other than that, perfectly drinkable and a pleasing mouthy finish. Very drinkable compared to a lot of Scottish ales where you may need a roaring fire and a view of some kind of slope ((; / yah maan.
Pours a nice dark orange color with off-white head. Sweetness, roasted malt, nuts, and caramel on the nose; follows onto the palate. Very nice scotch ale.
Draft - Sweet grains and a bit of caramel. Deep amber with a thin beige head. Bit of grains and caramel, nothing fancy and a bit of whiskey sweet finish. Nice and simply well done.

on draft at Holy Grail; really starting to like this style and Peticolas is always solid. aroma of malt, slight smoke, caramel. dark copper pour. Flavor like aroma - sweet but not cloying; there was also a stickiness at end that was great but not sure of flavor. niiiiiiiiice.
Rated at BTBF 2012 (Backlog). Hazy brown with a decent sized beige head. Aroma is of peat, light fudge, caramel. Taste is of toffee, caramel, peat, and smoked pecan shells.

Clear dark ruby brown with a foamy light beige head. The aroma is dark and malty with an earthy caratoffee aroma and a bit of leafy peat. The flavor is rich and dark with a sweet raisin and earthy toffee flavor, a wee bit peaty and earthy overall. Pretty fine scotch ale.

Decent Scottish ale. Nice sweet malty aroma. Dark brown color with a nice white head with some lacing. Medium weight palate with low carbonation. Full mouth feel. Flavors are heavy malt with some acidic sweetness. Very little hops. Good offering.

Tap at BTBF. Dark brown pour with creamy khaki head. Nose is caramel, plums, leather. Flavor is malty, caramel, plums, leather. Would like some smoked malts to counterbalance the sweetness. Syrupy mouthfeel.

From a growler filled at Tap and Growler. 

Very good, not great, beer from one of Dallas's great new breweries. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
hazy brown color with tan foam. Peat smoke, toffee, dark fruit aromas.  medium body. nutty, spicy caramel, smoke flavors--ok
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Tap at Oak St. Reddish brown pour with a thin off white head.  Sweet malty aroma. Taste caramel, nuts, and peat. Slight bitterness.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2017 On tap at BTBF. The smell is sweet, peat, hops, malts, and very sweet.  The look is red to amber in color with a beige colored head.  The smell is sweet, hops, peat, malts, and ok. 

Update. Had aged versions of this that were great. Nice smoke, ham, good stuff.

On tap. Pours with a muddy brown hue with a small tan head. Aromas are of brown sugar, malty, hints of smoke, odd esters. Flavors are brown sugar, smoke, apples, malty, peat, nutty. Overly estery with apples and pears, medium bubbles, low bitterness.
(Draught)  Pours a copper-brown body with a medium tan head.  Aroma of caramel, brown sugar, light peat, raisins, and toffee.  Flavor of raisins, caramel, peat, and grain.
Poured at the Big Texas Beer Festival.  Medium pour with an off-white head.  Aroma is dark fruit, light mossy peat, and nuts.  Taste is light smoke, lots of roast, sour chocolate, and plums.

On tap @ BTBF.
Reddish brown pour with some off-white head.  Nose of dark fruit, sugar sweetness, and some smoke.  Flavors of caramel, more dark fruit, and just a touch of peat/smoke.  This is tasty and super easy drinking!
On tap at Big Texas Beer Featival. Aroma of malty goodness. Deep brown clear color with a white-tan head. Taste of caramel, bread, hay, roasty malts. Smooth on the way down. Great brew!!

In tap. Pours dark brown with rich tan head. Aroma of faint stone fruit Easters with subtle hints of toffee and burnt caramel. Flavor is very balanced with hints of toffee, burnt caramel, hints of dark grain, very subtle spice, very faint dark fruit. Medium-heavy body, medium carbonation. Overall, I had two servings in a row of this brew, very easy drinking and enjoyable!

Very nice full bodied and malty.  Pretty good scotch ale. Just a tiny bit soupy.  Not quite in top of class but very close. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured a deep brown, almost cola color with very thin head. Huge raosted malt all over the palate. Very, very nice.
Deep brown almost black with a khaki head.  Nose is caramel, dried fruits, sticky, light toffee, and faint roast.  Smooth palate, rich caramel, peat, smoke, faint fruit, and a slightly sticky finish.

On tap at Holy grail, pour is a dark amber with cream head..Nose is caramel, nutty, toffee,vanilla, faint wood...Taste is caramel, toffee, chewy malts, hay, dark candy,honey ..Palate is warm and very thick..Super solid

(draught) clear deep red-brown with tight tan bubbles that last. Nose of juicy dark fruit, cream, brown sugar. Taste of very light peat, balanced, dark fruit, lightly smoky in a good way. Body is awesome. Very well carbonated, raisins, creamy and delicious.
On tap at the Holy Grail in Plano, TX.  Taste is caramel, malt and oak.  Smooth and very drinkable.

On tap at the Holy Grail. The beer pours a deep reddish-brown color with a tan head. The aroma has a lot of toffee and dark fruit notes, with a lite bit of peet malt. There is also a hint of smoke and some alcohol. The flavor is heavy on the malt, with some peet and caramel notes coming through first. There is also a little smoke and some dark cherry notes and alcohol. Medium, creamy mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
on tap, dark suede brown with tan foam, nice aroma and flavor of caramel toffee that melds well with the whiskey notes, good mild finish
